docs.lead_paragraph: EIGHT years ago, Robert Crandall, at the time chairman of the parent company of American Airlines, famously threatened to allow American to go out of business if he could not get the airline's costs down. Today, Mr. Crandall's successors at American and other airlines face the same predicament. This time the decision to fold may be out of their hands. The combination of falling sales and rising costs has put every major carrier, with the exception of Southwest Airlines, at risk of failure, said Peter Walsh, an aviation expert at Mercer Management Consulting. The agreement Congress reached on Thursday to give the federal government control over security at airports for three years may make passengers feel more secure, but it will not fix the industry's structural crisis, Mr. Walsh said.

headline.main: Ideas & Trends; Cry for Help: This Industry Doesn't Fly

docs.abstract: US airline industry is in serious trouble; combination of falling sales and rising costs has put every major carrier, with exception of Southwest Airlines, at risk of failure; agreement Congress reaches to give federal government control over security at airports for three years may make passengers feel more secure, but will not fix industry's structural crisis; sharply rising labor costs, high taxes and overexpansion put airlines on brink of crisis even before Sept 11 terrorist attacks; terrorist attacks worsened industry's problems, causing pssenger traffic to plunge more quickly than airlines could cut expenses, as well as generating huge new costs for security and insurance; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN recent weeks, a steady parade of executives from industries like airlines and insurance companies, hotels and pharmaceutical companies, has trooped to Washington for handouts. Some have walked away with billions in aid. But those pleas pale when compared with the all-out lobbying push now under way -- a fight for broad and deep corporate tax cuts that are being measured in the hundreds of billions of dollars. Lining up in the corridors of the Capitol and the White House are the chief executives of some of the biggest corporations: Philip M. Condit of Boeing, Rick Wagoner of General Motors, Charles O. Holliday Jr. of DuPont, Glen A. Barton of Caterpillar, William T. Esrey of Sprint and John T. Dillon of International Paper, among others.

headline.main: So, Friend, It's Time for That Tax Cut

docs.abstract: All-out lobbying effort is under way for broad and deep corporate tax cuts that are being measured in hundreds of billions of dollars; current betting is that corporate America will get much of what it wants, including faster write-offs on new capital investments, more liberal use of tax losses and some changes in alternative minimum tax; lobbyists say improved cash flow derived from cuts would enable companies to invest in their businesses and save jobs; critics say that business tax cuts will do little to spur consumer demand, that there is no assurance that companies will use fresh money in economically productive ways and that additional capital investment could only add more drag to an economy already suffering from overcapacity; drawing; photo; chart (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A group of large Florida employers, including Lockheed Martin, Walt Disney World and Universal Studios, has decided to give financial rewards to doctors who meet certain quality standards and are highly rated by their patients. The group, called the Central Florida Health Care Coalition, said yesterday that it had obtained combined ''clinical, financial and patient-satisfaction data'' on individual local doctors for the first time.

headline.main: Florida Employers Will Offer Incentives to Doctors

docs.lead_paragraph: A staggering 79,000 jobs disappeared from New York City in October, government officials announced yesterday, signaling that all the dire forecasts of economic fallout from the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks may have been understated. Public and private forecasters have been predicting that 80,000 to 115,000 jobs would evaporate in the wake of the World Trade Center disaster -- but not all in one month.

headline.main: Loss of 79,000 Jobs Adds to City's Economic Woes

docs.abstract: New York City loses staggering 79,000 jobs in October, signal that economic fallout from Sept 11 terrorist attacks may be even worse than forecast; number of jobs usually rises in October; fraction of lost jobs are Wall Street positions that moved to New Jersey; most of decline comes from businesses laying off workers or simply closing for good; enormous job losses are announced as other new reports outline economic damage city has suffered since terrorists destroyed trade center; unemployment rate in city falls slightly, from 6.3 percent to 6.2 percent when adjusted for seasonal factors; this probably reflects fact tha many people who lost jobs are too discouraged or too traumatized to look for new ones; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It was the kind of Election Day enterprise that usually slips under the radar, a local nonbinding resolution about health insurance at a time when the nation is consumed by matters of war and terrorism. Most people expected a low-budget campaign and low-static vote with little teeth to it. Instead, a vote this month in Portland on whether Maine should become the first state with universal health care could be the beginning of a new round in the nation's health care debate.

headline.main: Small Vote for Universal Care Is Seen as Carrying a Lot of Weight

docs.lead_paragraph: The World Trade Center's largest insurer said yesterday that a demand for an immediate payment by the developer who holds the lease to the complex was signaling his decision not to rebuild. Lawyers for the insurer, the SR International Business Insurance Company, an affiliate of the Swiss Reinsurance Company, known as Swiss Re, made that argument in a letter to lawyers for the developer, Larry A. Silverstein.

docs.lead_paragraph: An article published this month in The New England Journal of Medicine reports a startling discovery: The ''gatekeeper'' physicians who are thought to be so essential to health maintenance organizations may actually do little to reduce costs or block patients' access to specialists. In 1998 Harvard Vanguard Medical Associates decided to stop requiring its members to see a general practitioner before contacting a specialist, such as an oncologist or cardiologist. A team of researchers led by Dr. Timothy G. Ferris of Massachusetts General Hospital followed Harvard Vanguard's members for six months before and after the change. They found almost no difference in the use of specialists in the two periods. This could imply that gatekeepers do little to limit access to specialists and, by extension, contain costs.
docs.abstract: Editorial on article in The New England Journal of Medicine, reporting that 'gatekeeper' physicians thought to be so essential to health maintenance organizations may do little to reduce costs or block patients' access to specialists; says if further studies back up these findings, industry could safely scale back role that never fulfilled its early promise and mostly annoyed both patients and their doctors

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-16 Nations Back Freer Trade, Hoping to Aid Global Growth Trade ministers from more than 140 nations meeting in Qatar agreed on an agenda to topple tariffs and liberalize trade on an array of items as diverse as wheat and insurance. The consensus ended six days of talks in which the World Trade Organization members sought to balance national interests against an urgent need to shore up the world economy. A12 New U.S. Strategy on Mideast Secretary of State Colin L. Powell is poised to present a new, more active American strategy to end the killing between Israelis and Palestinians and restart talks aimed at establishing a Palestinian state, perhaps as early as next week, officials said. docs.lead_paragraph: Reaching a consensus that they hope will rejuvenate the world's economy, trade ministers from more than 140 nations agreed today on an agenda to topple tariffs and liberalize trade on everything from wheat to insurance policies. In six days of nearly round-the-clock meetings in this Persian Gulf emirate, the members of the World Trade Organization sought to balance their national interests against the urgent need to shore up the world's battered economy. Their success helped to dispel some of the psychological damage inflicted by the collapse of similar talks in Seattle two years ago.

headline.main: Nations Back Freer Trade, Hoping to Aid Global Growth

docs.abstract: Trade ministers from more than 140 nations agree on agenda to topple tariffs and liberalize trade on everything from wheat to insurance policies; members of World Trade Orgn seek, in six days of nearly round-the-clock meetings in Doha, Qatar, to balance their national interests against urgent need to shore up world's battered economy; trade is growing at slowest rate since early 1980's and world economy is on brink of recession, putting intense pressure on negotiators to act together to stimulate growth; World Bank estimates that outline agreed on could help add $2.8 trillion to global economic activity by 2015; photos (M)
